docs.lead_paragraph: The Department of Veterans Affairs will propose new regulations to make it easier for veterans to receive treatment for illnesses linked to traumatic brain injury.

headline.seo: Benefit Rules Eased for Veterans With Brain Injuries
headline.main: Rules Eased for Veterans’ Brain Injury Benefits
headline.print_headline: Rules Eased for Veterans’ Brain Injury Benefits

docs.abstract: Veterans Affairs Department will propose new regulations to make it easier for thousands of veterans to receive health care and compensation for certain illnesses that have been linked to traumatic brain injury.
docs.snippet: The Department of Veterans Affairs will propose new regulations to make it easier for veterans to receive treatment for illnesses linked to traumatic brain injury.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: As states finalize what benefits they want guaranteed under the new health care law, it is becoming increasingly clear that what services are received will vary in part by location.

headline.seo: Interest Groups Push to Fill Margins of Health Coverage
headline.main: Interest Groups Push to Fill Margins of Health Coverage
headline.print_headline: Interest Groups Push to Fill Margins of Health Coverage

docs.abstract: Main goal of new health care law is to guarantee medical coverage to nearly all Americans, but as states finalize their insurance benefits packages, it is becoming clear that what services are received will depend partly on location; interest groups are lobbying in different states to add services like chiropractor care and infertility treatments to package of essential benefits insurance must cover under the law.
docs.snippet: As states finalize what benefits they want guaranteed under the new health care law, it is becoming increasingly clear that what services are received will vary in part by location.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The index ranks pharmaceutical companies based on how readily they get medicines to the world’s poor, how much research they do on tropical diseases and how ethically they conduct clinical trials.

headline.seo: GlaxoSmithKline Tops Access to Medicines Index
headline.main: Pharmaceuticals: GlaxoSmithKline Retains Top Ranking Measuring Outreach to Poor Countries
headline.print_headline: Pharmaceuticals: GlaxoSmithKline Retains Top Ranking Measuring Outreach to Poor Countries

docs.abstract: GlaxoSmithKline holds on to top spot in Access to Medicines Index, which ranks world's top 20 pharmaceutical companies in terms of how readily they get medicines to world's poor; index does, however, show other competitors closing in.
docs.snippet: The index ranks pharmaceutical companies based on how readily they get medicines to the world’s poor, how much research they do on tropical diseases and how ethically they conduct clinical trials.

docs.lead_paragraph: Computer programs offer a backup for doctors facing tricky symptoms, but are still far from replacing a skilled diagnostician.

headline.seo: Software Programs Help Doctors Diagnose, but Can’t Replace Them
headline.main: For Second Opinion, Consult a Computer?
headline.print_headline: Could a Computer Outthink This Doctor?

docs.abstract: Computers are a valuable tool for doctors attempting to identify diseases in patients, but they may never replace expert diagnosticians like Dr Gurpreet Dhaliwal of San Francisco, considered one of the most skillful clinical diagnosticians in practice today; he exemplifies doctors who can combine logic and knowledge with pattern-matching instincts while overcoming hindrances, like incomplete or imprecise information, that could cause a computer system to makes serious diagnostic errors.
docs.snippet: Computer programs offer a backup for doctors facing tricky symptoms, but are still far from replacing a skilled diagnostician.

docs.abstract: Addressing a question asked frequently during a research trip to Antarctica: Why should the human race invest its precious and finite resources into space exploration?
docs.snippet: Addressing a question asked frequently during a research trip to Antarctica: Why should the human race invest its precious and finite resources into space exploration?

docs.lead_paragraph: The little creature of the sea that appears to debunk the most fundamental law of the natural world: you are born, and then you die.

headline.main: Can a Jellyfish Unlock the Secret of Immortality?

docs.abstract: Nathaniel Rich article on Turritopsis dohrnii, more commonly known as immortal jellyfish, which appears to live forever; examines research done on species by Shin Kubota, only marine biologist who manages to consistently culture genus in his lab.
docs.snippet: The little creature of the sea that appears to debunk the most fundamental law of the natural world: you are born, and then you die.
